alert.note: Alert for Adams; Billings; Bottineau; Bowman; Burke; Burleigh; Dickey; Divide; Dunn; Emmons; Foster; Golden Valley; Grant; Hettinger; Kidder; LaMoure; Logan; McHenry; McIntosh; McKenzie; McLean; Mercer; Morton; Mountrail; Oliver; Pierce; Renville; Rolette; Sheridan; Sioux; Slope; Stark; Stutsman; Ward; Wells; Williams (North Dakota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 07 at 2:35PM CDT by NWS Bismarck
info.description: ...MELTING SNOW TO START CREATING RUNOFF EASTER WEEKEND... Melting snow will increasingly begin to establish pathways to the rivers and streams of North Dakota over the Easter weekend. Some of the more prominent rivers and streams that are already receiving runoff include: - The Cedar Creek and Cannonball River watersheds. - Upper portion of the Heart River near Dickinson. - The Little Missouri River up through Medora and on over to the North Unit of Theodore Roosevelt National Park. -The Knife River above Manning and all the way over to Hazen. -The Little Muddy River near Williston. -The Yellowstone River out in Montana. This pattern of developing runoff will work its way eastward over the coming weekend to where runoff is expected to make its way to the following rivers and streams: -Beaver Creek below Linton, along with its upstream branches near Zeeland and Strasburg. -Square Butte Creek in northeastern Morton County. -Apple Creek near Menoken. -Burnt and Hay creeks in Burleigh County. -Painted Woods and Turtle Creeks near Washburn. By early next week, this pattern of developing runoff will likely make its way out into the Prairie Pothole Region and cause all lakes and wetlands in closed, or semi-closed basins to begin to rise. Other small streams and rivers that should be expected to produce strong runoff include: -White Earth River in Mountrail County. -Deepwater Creek in McLean County. By the middle of the second full week of April, runoff should commence in the James River basin, this includes: -Pipestem Creek and the James River above Jamestown. -Cottonwood, Bonehill and Beaver creeks and the James River below I-94 near Jamestown. -The Maple River and Elm rivers in Dickey County. Normally the last major river basin to become active in North Dakota is the Souris (Mouse) River Basin. However, given the significant warming trend going forth, the Souris and all of its tributaries including the following rivers are likely to receive significant runoff around the middle of the second week of April. These other rivers and streams include: -The Des Lacs and Wintering rivers. -Deep Creek and all the coulees north and west of Minot. -Willow Creek. -Long Creek in divide County. Rapid rises are expected in nearly all rivers and streams draining western and central North Dakota, but dry soils underlying the snowpack are still expected to temper the runoff. However, flooding of nearby low-lying areas is a distinct risk going forward.
